I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2011  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide policy and 
advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Fiscal  Policy  for  Urbanization,  Industrialization,  and 
Agricultural  Modernization  in  Henan.  Following  consultations  with  the  Henan  provincial 
government and other stakeholders on 22–25 May 2012, a TA fact-finding mission on 19–20 
July 2012 agreed on the objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, costs, and terms of 
reference. The mission also assessed the executing agency’s capacity to implement the TA. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Henan is located in the central region of the PRC. It is one of the country’s most 
populous provinces, with over 91 million inhabitants in 2010. Its gross domestic product (GDP), 
however, accounted for only 5.3% of the country’s GDP, compared with 7.5% of population 
share. Per capita GDP remained at 70.7% of the national average. Henan is one of the major 
grain-producing regions in the country and is ranked first in wheat production and second in 
corn. However, the rapid economic growth and massive emigration of farmers to cities has left 
the  agriculture  sector  and  rural  communities  under  stress.  Arable  land  is  vulnerable  to 
urbanization and industrialization, agricultural infrastructure has been neglected, and agriculture 
productivity is declining. The traditional village-based rural community is collapsing, as adults 
travel to cities as migrant workers and most families are left with only the elderly and children. 
This puts pressure on the provincial government to maintain quality social services including 
medical, education, and solid waste management. 
 
3.  Balanced  rural–urban  development  combined  with  industrialization  can  boost 
consumption, provide better social services (e.g., education, health, and social safety nets), and 
mitigate adverse economic and social issues that usually accompany rapid urbanization. Henan 
has already taken the initial steps to maximize the potential benefits from a growing urban 
population, an emerging industrial base, and a strong agricultural sector. 
 
4.  Urbanization. The urban population of the PRC has grown significantly in the last 
30 years,  from  19.4%  of  the  total  population  in  1980  to  49.9%  in  2010.  In  Henan,  the 
urbanization  rate  of 38.8%  in  2010  was  significantly  lower  than  the  national  rate  but  it  is 
expected to rise to 50% by 2020. Henan is exploring new approaches to urbanization through 
cost-effective, resource-saving, environmentally friendly, socially harmonious, and coordinated 
urban–rural  development  schemes.  Recently,  Henan  introduced  a  new  modality  of 
urbanization—new-type rural communities as the lowest level of urban center, in addition to the 
existing four levels of the urban administrative structure.2 Each new-type rural community will 
consolidate small and contiguous villages of more than 5,000 inhabitants into one, and increase 
at least 2,000 mu (about 1.3 square kilometers [km2]) of farmland.3  
 
5.  Industrialization. Industrialization in Henan is gaining momentum, supported by the 
regionally  balanced  development  effort  of  the  central  government  and  planned  transfer  of 
industries from coastal regions to further inland. In addition to establishing industrial clusters, 
Henan introduced the concept of new industrialization, which emphasizes the coexistence of

industries and people in the same area. More specifically, new industrialization will build a 
modern industrial system featuring optimal infrastructure, advanced technologies that are clean 
and safe, and high value addition, while saving farmlands and reducing human migration to 
large cities, providing more employment and better social services, and mitigating negative 
environmental impacts. 
 
6.   Agricultural modernization. In response to challenges to the agriculture and rural 
areas, the PRC Government has recently placed higher priority on agricultural development. A 
series of new policies to support farmers and enhance scientific innovation and development for 
the agricultural sector are included in the No. 1 Central Document in 2012, jointly released by 
the Communist Party of China Central Committee and the State Council. As a major agricultural 
producer  in  the  country,  Henan  is  striving  to  become  the  nation’s  breadbasket,4 and  the 
provincial government recognizes the urgent need to modernize its agriculture sector and to 
strengthen  efforts  to  increase  agricultural  productivity  through  technological  advances  and 
diversification into higher value activities. Farmlands and the environment need to be protected 
as  cities  expand  to  peri-urban  areas,  causing  adverse  effects  on  green  production,  the 
environment, and ecology. 
 
7.  Integrated  strategy  for  development.  The  integrated  transformation  concept  was 
introduced in the mid-1990s by the leader of Henan provincial government. Henan provincial 
government approved the Outline of Construction of Henan Province into the Central Plains 
Economic Zone in October 2010. The outline was adopted by the central government as a 
national strategy. Subsequently, in October 2011 the PRC’s State Council issued a guideline to 
support Henan’s efforts to speed up the development of the Central Plains Economic Zone, 
which includes Henan and its neighboring provinces of Shangxi, Shangdong, Heibei, and Anhui. 
The  guideline  positioned  the  zone  as  a  national  model  for  integrating  urbanization, 
industrialization, and agricultural modernization processes—otherwise known as the integrated 
three transformations (sanhua).5 The provincial government indicated its strong commitment to 
the integrated three transformations under the 12th Development Plan of Henan Province, 
2011–2015.  The  government  believes  that,  while  agriculture  modernization  serves  as  the 
foundation and industrialization provides the impetus, the new urbanization process is the key to 
integrated economic development. 
 
8.  A comprehensive list of key drivers for the successful implementation of the integrated 
three transformations has yet to be compiled.6 Key stakeholders agreed on the importance of 
enhanced  fiscal  policy,  given  the  planned  scale  and  scope  of  the  integrated  three 
transformations. The current fiscal position of Henan is weak; its tax, budget, and expenditure 
systems are not well developed; and 83% of total expenditure in 2011 was funded by fiscal 
transfers from the central government. Henan’s per capita fiscal expenditure is the lowest 
among all provinces. Furthermore, since the recent global financial crisis, the ability of the 
central government to provide fiscal support to the provincial governments has declined. Thus, 
financing requirements of Henan’s various development initiatives have to be met increasingly 
by the provincial government. Well designed and implemented fiscal policies—including budget, 
expenditure, taxes, fees and subsidies, and fiscal transfers—will be needed to (i) give proper

incentives  to  the  authorities  at  various  levels  of  government  to  pursue  an  integrated  and 
balanced approach, (ii) attract active participation of the private sector and encourage foreign 
direct investments, and (iii) meet the interests of various stakeholders and provide equitable 
levels of social services. 
 
9.  In this context, Henan provincial government requested ADB for TA for identifying an 
appropriate development approach, and prioritizing areas for government support, particularly 
fiscal support. The TA is consistent with the inclusive growth agenda, one of the three pillars of 
the strategic framework in the PRC’s country partnership strategy, 2011–2015.7 It will contribute 
to the balanced development of rural and urban areas, and will cover two priority sectors of the 
strategy—agriculture  and  urban  development.  The  TA  is  included  in  the  2012  indicative 
assistance  pipeline  for  nonlending  products  and  services  of  the  PRC  country  operations 
business plan, 2012–2014.8 
   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
10.  The impact will be a better integrated urbanization, industrialization, and agricultural 
modernization process in Henan. The attainment of this impact will be demonstrated through the 
completion of new-type rural communities, Henan’s share in the national industrial output, and 
farmland areas. The outcome will be effective fiscal policy to support the integrated three 
transformations  from  the  traditional  agriculture  economy  and  rural  society  to  one  that  is 
urbanized and industrialized with a modernized agriculture sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
11.  The TA will assist Henan provincial government to analyze the interlinkages among 
various  aspects  of  urbanization,  industrialization,  and  agricultural  modernization;  and  will 
formulate effective fiscal policy recommendations to support integrated development led by new 
urbanization. Building on previous TA projects,9 the TA will focus on defining fiscal policy 
choices  to  support  the  integrated  three  transformations  development  strategy.  The  policy 
recommendations will be made relevant not only to Henan and the central government, but also 
to the neighboring provinces included in the Central Plains Economic Zone. The TA findings can 
also serve as case studies for further work of the government and ADB on local government 
financing  and  fiscal  decentralization.  Key  activities  of  the  TA  will  comprise  two  phases: 
(i) conducting  background  studies  and  identifying  key  drivers  of  the  integrated  three 
transformations; and (ii) preparing fiscal strategy and policy to promote the integrated three 
transformations, directly and through the contributions of other drivers. At the initial stage, an 
inception  workshop  will  be  held  with  the  executing  agency,  researchers,  and  other  key 
stakeholders to discuss the feasibility and viability of the TA implementation plan. In each phase, 
a  workshop  will  be  held  to  discuss  major  findings  and  implications  of  the  draft  reports. 
Government officials and experts in relevant fields will be invited to gather their inputs and 
improve  draft  reports.  International  study  visits  will  be  organized  to  learn  from  foreign 
experiences related to development of fiscal policy for the integrated three transformations. A

final dissemination workshop will take place and knowledge products will be produced toward 
the end of the TA. 
 
12.   The outputs will be (i) analysis of key constraints and drivers for the integrated three 
transformations, and (ii) fiscal policy for the integrated three transformations. The TA will deliver 
two background reports during the first phase of project implementation and five special reports 
and  a  comprehensive  strategy  report  in  the  second  phase.  Knowledge  products  will  be 
produced based on all the reports. 
(i)  Background  reports.  A  background  report  will  identify  key  drivers  of  the 
integrated three transformations. Another report will develop key indicators to 
monitor  and  evaluate  the  progress  of  the  integrated  three  transformations 
strategy at the provincial, municipality, and community levels as well as different 
regions  in  the  province.  The  TA  will  conduct  a  field  survey  on  the  current 
transformation status.  
(ii)  Special reports. These will include one report on fiscal policy as the tool for 
integrated development, three reports on the selected key drivers, and one report 
for new-type rural community development. The first four special reports will 
analyze  the  identified  key  drivers  at  provincial,  municipality,  and  community 
levels. Each report will provide policy recommendations, focusing on fiscal policy, 
in the policy notes. 
(iii)  Strategy report. This will summarize the background and special reports. It will 
draw conclusions and provide strategic fiscal policy recommendations to support 
the  integrated  three  transformations  strategy  of  both  the central  and  Henan 
governments.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space,  domestic 
transportation, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions; and finance additional 
domestic and international study visits. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
14.   Henan provincial department of finance (DOF) will be the executing and implementing 
agency. DOF will be responsible for the overall execution and coordination of TA activities and 
for designating a project coordinator for day-to-day TA implementation. DOF will, in coordination 
with ADB, provide necessary guidance to consultants, particularly to ensure study consistency 
and avoid any overlap. Consultants will discuss the study framework with DOF and ADB, and 
regularly report to them on study progress and results. In ADB, the East Asia Department’s 
Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional Cooperation Division will be in charge of 
the TA implementation and coordination with the Urban and Social Sectors Division and the 
Environment, Natural Resources, and Agriculture Division on the aspects of urbanization and 
agriculture modernization. 
 
15.   The TA is included in the list of delegated TA projects for 2012. The fact-finding mission 
reviewed DOF capacity for procurement and managing consulting services for the TA. As only 
individual  consultants  are  intended  to  be  selected,  simplified  capacity  assessment  was 
conducted. The review  found that  DOF  had sufficient  experience  in  implementing  projects

5 
funded by ADB and the World Bank, including procurement and supervising consulting services 
involving  international  consultants.  The  assessment  concluded  that  DOF’s  capacity  was 
adequate to recruit individual consultants and manage the study, and recommended approving 
the delegation of the TA to DOF.10 In line with the enhanced partnership approach,11 delegation 
is  limited  to  the  selection  of  international  and  national  consultants,  short-term  resource 
persons,  and  task-specific  experts.  ADB  will  negotiate  and  sign  the  contracts  with  them. 
Therefore, ADB will have final responsibility for implementing the contracts and will take all 
decisions that are required under the contracts. DOF will recommend actions to ADB under the 
contracts and will be consulted by ADB on all contract-related actions.  Subject to the foregoing, 
after contract signing, implementation will be supported by DOF. 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 20 months starting on 1 December 2012 and ending 
on 31 July 2014. The TA will be carried out by a team of international (3 person-months) and 
national consultants (24 person-months) having extensive knowledge and expertise in public 
finance, development economics, urban development, rural development, and development 
survey. The consultants will deliver, in both English and Chinese, a comprehensive report 
comprising eight studies. They will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 3. TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). No procurement is 
envisioned. DOF may use an advance payment facility to conduct seminars and workshops. 
 
17.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by DOF, as well as by 
ADB  review  missions.  Consultants’  reports  will  be  presented  at  workshops  and  seminars 
organized to validate findings. Reports will be made available on ADB website in English and 
Chinese and published in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2011). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Fiscal  Policy  for  Urbanization, 
Industrialization, and Agricultural Modernization in Henan, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will assist Henan provincial government in analyzing the 
interlinkages among urbanization, industrialization, and agricultural modernization processes—
otherwise known as the integrated three transformations; and formulating fiscal policy to support 
their integrated development, led by new urbanization. 
 
2.  The consultants will perform their tasks in consultation with Henan provincial department 
of finance, and other central, provincial, and local government departments and agencies to 
ensure acceptance of the TA outcome. The TA will require 3 person-months of international and 
24 person-months of national inputs and will be completed within 20 months. 
 
B.  Consulting Requirements 
3.  Public  finance  specialist  (international,  3  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
international specialist will advise the senior public finance specialist (team leader) and other 
specialists on the fiscal aspects of the special and strategy reports. The international specialist 
should have a PhD degree (or a senior professional title) and expertise gained from at least 
10 years’  international  and  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)1 experience  in  fiscal  policy, 
supported by proven achievements. Specifically, the international specialist will carry out, but 
will not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  review existing studies on Henan’s industry development, urban development, 
agriculture development, and fiscal policy including the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) TA for Fiscal Policy Support for Economic Development in Henan;2 
(ii)  prepare  a  report  on  international  and  domestic  experiences,  and  their 
implications relevant to the integrated three transformations, focusing on fiscal 
policy; 
(iii)  advise on the overall study framework and approaches; 
(iv)  provide theoretical and practical advice to the team leader and other specialists 
on the fiscal aspects of each report; and 
(v)  advise on the framework of other reports and conduct peer reviews, focusing on 
fiscal policy.  
 
4.  Senior  public  finance  specialist—team  leader  (national,  7  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist will lead the study on fiscal policy to support the integrated three 
transformations.  The  specialist  will  prepare  the  strategy  report,  including  holistic 
recommendations, and draft an effective strategy and policy for the successful integrated three 
transformations. The specialist should have a PhD degree (or a senior professional title) and 
15 years experience in relevant fields, with proven experience in fiscal policy consultancy in the 
central PRC. The specialist should have good communication skills to liaise efficiently with both 
government and academic circles. Specifically, the specialist will carry out, but will not be limited 
to, the following tasks:  
(i)  take overall responsibility for the studies under the TA, including planning and 
coordination of overall activities, delivery of all outputs, and coordination among 
consultants, the government, and ADB;

(iv)  identify the financial, fiscal, labor, social, environmental, resettlement, among 
others, constraints that limit and the key drivers that promote the integrated three 
transformations strategy; 
(v)  prioritize the key drivers and examine international and domestic experiences in 
addressing similar issues; 
(vi)  analyze existing fiscal policy from the integrated three transformations aspect, 
including the structure and sustainability of municipal finance; 
(vii)  prepare  special  reports  on  fiscal  policy  to  support  the  integrated  three 
transformations  strategy,  particularly  on  the  enhancement  of  basic  public 
services,  development  of  new-type  rural  communities,  balanced  urban  and

(viii)  prepare a brief policy note on recommendations for fiscal policy and an action 
plan to implement the recommendations; and 
(ix)  building  on  the  background  and  special  reports,  prepare  a  comprehensive 
strategy report, with separate fiscal policy recommendations and action plans for 
the central and Henan governments. 
 
5.  Development  survey  specialist  (national,  2.5  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialist  will  conduct  a  field  survey  on  the  current  transformation  profile  and  prepare  a 
background report to support the special reports on the key drivers of the integrated three 
transformations. The specialist should ideally have a PhD degree (or a senior professional title) 
and  5  years  experience  in  relevant  fields,  particularly  statistics,  with  in-depth  research 
experience in the central PRC. Specifically, the specialist will carry out, but will not be limited to, 
the following tasks: 
(i)  convene a meeting of experts in the integrated three transformations to clarify the 
purpose of the survey, type of information to be collected, survey modality, etc.; 
(ii)  craft the questions, format the questionnaire, and conduct a field survey;  
(iii)  provide the model analysis; 
(iv)  collect and process data using the statistical analysis software;  
(v)  conduct quantitative analysis  necessary for identifying the key drivers of the 
integrated three transformations;  
(vi)  prepare  a  profile  of  the  integrated  three  transformations  and  identify  key 
characteristics of the integrated three transformations; and 
(vii)  develop key indicators to monitor and evaluate the progress of the integrated 
three transformations at the provincial, municipality, and community levels; and 
different regions in the province. 
  
6.  Urban  development  economist  (national,  4  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
economist will prepare a background report to identify the key drivers of the integrated three 
transformations.  The  economist  will  seek  the  guidance  of  the  international  public  finance 
specialist and coordinate with the development survey specialist. The economist should ideally 
have a PhD (or a senior professor title) and 7 years experience in relevant fields, including 
urban development. Specifically, the economist will carry out, but will not be limited to, the 
following tasks: 
                                                
3  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Fiscal Policy Support for Economic 
Development in Henan. Manila (TA 7192-PRC).

Appendix 3  11 
(i)  review  the  background  studies  on  Henan’s  industry  development,  urban 
development, agriculture development, and fiscal policy; 
(ii)  conduct consultations with key stakeholders, including minorities and small and 
medium-sized enterprises; 
(iii)  coordinate  with  the  development  survey  specialist  and  examine  the  survey 
results; 
(iv)  examine  linkages  among  the  urbanization,  industrialization,  and  agricultural 
modernization;  
(v)  identify key factors to consider in the integrated three transformations; 
(vi)  based on the evaluation of the key factors, propose a list of key drivers of the 
integrated  three  transformations;  develop  a  theoretical  model  and  analysis 
framework to be applied to the special studies on key drivers; and 
(vii)  finalize the background report. 
 
7.  Rural development specialist (national, 3 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
will prepare a special report on rural community development to promote the integrated three 
transformations. The specialist should ideally have a PhD (or a senior professor title) and 
7 years experience in relevant fields, including rural development and fiscal policy. Specifically, 
the specialist will carry out, but will not be limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct a domestic and international literature survey; review existing studies 
and reports, and summarize the central and Henan governments’ policy on key 
relevant issues;  
(ii)  provide a more detailed analysis of the rationale for the key driver; identify and 
prioritize constraints—financial, fiscal, labor, social, environmental, resettlement, 
etc.—that limit rural community development to promote the integrated three 
transformations; 
(iii)  assess  the  current  fiscal  policy,  analyze  its  functions  and  mechanism,  and 
compile international and domestic experience in addressing the constraints and 
other similar issues;  
(iv)  analyze  the  rural  community  development  from  the  integrated  three 
transformations aspects; 
(v)  prepare  a  special  report  on  rural  community  development  to  support  the 
integrated three transformations, particularly on inclusive basic public services, 
resettlement, environment, social and economic issues, and necessary reforms; 
and 
(vi)  prepare  a  brief  policy  note  on  recommendations  for  rural  community 
development and action plans to implement the recommendations. 
 
8.  Development  economists (three  national  experts,  7.5  person-months,  intermittent). 
The  economists  will  prepare  special  reports  on  three  key  drivers  of  the  integrated  three 
transformations. Each economist should ideally have a PhD degree (or a senior professor title) 
and 5 years experience in relevant fields, including the selected drivers of the integrated three 
transformations and public finance. Specifically, the economists will carry out, but will not be 
limited to, the following tasks: 
(i)  conduct a domestic and international literature survey; review existing studies 
and reports, and summarize the central and Henan governments’ policy on key 
relevant issues;  
(ii)  provide a more detailed analysis of the rationale for the key drivers; identify and 
prioritize constraints—financial, fiscal, labor, social, environmental, resettlement, 
etc.—that limit the key drivers to promote the integrated three transformations;

(iii)  assess  the  current  fiscal  policy,  analyze  its  functions  and  mechanism,  and 
compile international and domestic experience in addressing the constraints and 
other similar issues;   
(iv)  analyze the key drivers from the integrated three transformations aspects; 
(v)  prepare  special  reports  on  the  key  drivers  to  support  the  integrated  three 
transformations,  particularly  on  inclusive  basic  public  services,  resettlement, 
environment, social and economic issues, and necessary reforms; and
